# Amen

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the interjection. For other uses, see [Amen
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Amen_\(disambiguation\) "Amen \(disambiguation\)").

The word _**amen**_ ([/ˌɑːˈmɛn/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") or
[/ˌeɪˈmɛn/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"))[a] is a declaration of
affirmation[1][2] found in the [Hebrew Bible](/wiki/Hebrew_Bible "Hebrew
Bible") and the [New Testament](/wiki/New_Testament "New Testament"). It is
found in Jewish, Christian, and in Sunni Muslim worship as a concluding word
or response to [prayers](/wiki/Prayer "Prayer").[2] Common English
translations of the word _amen_ include "verily" and "truly". It can also be
used colloquially to express strong agreement,[2] as in, for instance, _amen
to that_.[3]

## Pronunciation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amen&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Pronunciation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amen&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(May 2017)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
In English, the word _amen_ has two primary pronunciations, _ah-men_
(/ɑːˈmɛn/) or _ay-men_ (/eɪˈmɛn/),[4] with minor additional variation in
emphasis (the two syllables may be equally stressed instead of placing primary
stress on the second).

In anglophone North America the _ah-men_ pronunciation is used in performances
of [classical music](/wiki/European_classical_music "European classical
music"), in churches with more formalized [rituals](/wiki/Ritual "Ritual") and
[liturgy](/wiki/Liturgy "Liturgy") and in liberal to mainline Protestant
denominations, as well as almost every Jewish congregation, in line with
modern Hebrew pronunciation. The _ay-men_ pronunciation, a product of the
[Great Vowel Shift](/wiki/Great_Vowel_Shift "Great Vowel Shift") dating to the
15th century, is associated with Irish Protestantism and conservative
[Evangelical](/wiki/Evangelical_Christianity "Evangelical Christianity")
denominations generally, and is the pronunciation typically used in [gospel
music](/wiki/Gospel_music "Gospel music").

In [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic "Arabic") the pronunciation _ah-meen_ (ʾĀmīn) is used
upon completing a [supplication to God](/wiki/Dua "Dua") or when concluding
recitation of the first surah [Al Fatiha](/wiki/Al_Fatiha "Al Fatiha") in
[prayer](/wiki/Salat "Salat").

## Etymology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amen&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Etymology")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Amen_in_East_Syriac_Aramaic_language.svg/150px-
Amen_in_East_Syriac_Aramaic_language.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Amen_in_East_Syriac_Aramaic_language.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Amen_in_East_Syriac_Aramaic_language.svg "Enlarge")

"Amen" in contemporary (_Madnhāyā_) [Syriac script](/wiki/Syriac_script
"Syriac script").

The usage of _Amen_ , meaning "so be it", as found in the early scriptures of
the [Bible](/wiki/Bible "Bible") is said to be of
[Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language") origin;[5] however, the
basic [triconsonantal root](/wiki/Triconsonantal_root "Triconsonantal root")
from which the word was derived is common to a number of languages, such as
[Aramaic](/wiki/Aramaic_language "Aramaic language"), in the [Semitic
branch](/wiki/Semitic_languages "Semitic languages") of the [Afrasian
languages](/wiki/Afrasian_languages "Afrasian languages"). The word was
imported into the Greek of the early Church from Judaism.[1][6] From Greek,
_amen_ entered the other Western languages. According to a standard dictionary
etymology, _amen_ passed from Greek into [Late Latin](/wiki/Late_Latin "Late
Latin"), and thence into English.[7] Rabbinic scholars from medieval France
believed the standard Hebrew word for faith _emuna_ comes from the root
_amen._ Although in English transliteration they look different, they are both
from the root [aleph](/wiki/Aleph "Aleph")-mem-nun. That is, the Hebrew word
_amen_ derives from the same ancient [triliteral](/wiki/Triliteral
"Triliteral") Hebrew root as does the verb _ʾāmán_.[8]

Grammarians frequently list _ʾāmán_ under its three consonants
(**[aleph](/wiki/Aleph "Aleph")-[mem](/wiki/Mem
"Mem")-[nun](/wiki/Nun_\(letter\) "Nun \(letter\)")**), which are identical to
those of _ʾāmēn_ (note that the Hebrew letter א _aleph_ represents a [glottal
stop](/wiki/Glottal_stop "Glottal stop") sound, which functions as a consonant
in the morphology of Hebrew).[7] This [triliteral](/wiki/Triliteral
"Triliteral") root means _to be firm, confirmed, reliable, faithful, have
faith, believe._

In [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"), the word is derived from
its [triliteral](/wiki/Triliteral "Triliteral") common root word ʾĀmana
([Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"): آمن‎), which has the same
meanings as the Hebrew root word.

Popular among some [theosophists](/wiki/Theosophy "Theosophy"),[9] proponents
of [Afrocentric](/wiki/Afrocentric "Afrocentric") theories of history,[10] and
adherents of [esoteric Christianity](/wiki/Esoteric_Christianity "Esoteric
Christianity")[11][12] is the [conjecture](/wiki/Conjecture "Conjecture") that
_amen_ is a derivative of the name of the [Egyptian god](/wiki/Egyptian_god
"Egyptian god") [Amun](/wiki/Amun "Amun") (which is sometimes also spelled
**Amen**). Some adherents of Eastern religions believe that _amen_ shares
roots with the Hindu [Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit "Sanskrit") word,
_[Aum](/wiki/Om "Om")_.[13][14][15][16] Such external etymologies are not
included in standard etymological reference works. The Hebrew word, as noted
above, starts with aleph, while the Egyptian name begins with a
[yodh](/wiki/Yodh "Yodh").[17]

The [Armenian](/wiki/Armenian_language "Armenian language") word
[ամեն](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D5%A1%D5%B4%D5%A5%D5%B6#Armenian
"wikt:ամեն") (_amen_) means "every"; however it is also used in the same form
at the conclusion of prayers, much as in English.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In
French, the Hebrew word _amen_ is sometimes translated as _Ainsi soit-il_ ,
which means "So be it."[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Hebrew Bible[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amen&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Hebrew Bible")]

The word first occurs in the [Hebrew Bible](/wiki/Hebrew_Bible "Hebrew Bible")
in Numbers 5:22 when the Priest addresses a suspected adulteress and she
responds “Amen, Amen”. Overall, the word appears in the Hebrew Bible 30 times.

Three distinct Biblical usages of _amen_ may be noted:[1]

  1. Initial _amen_ , referring back to words of another speaker and introducing an affirmative sentence, e.g. 1 [Kings](/wiki/Books_of_Kings "Books of Kings") 1:36.[1]
  2. Detached _amen_ , again referring to the words of another speaker but without a complementary affirmative sentence, e.g. Nehemiah 5:13.[1]
  3. Final _amen_ , with no change of speaker, as in the subscription to the first three divisions of [Psalms](/wiki/Psalms "Psalms").[1]

### New Testament[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amen&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: New Testament")]

There are 52 amens in the [Synoptic Gospels](/wiki/Synoptic_Gospels "Synoptic
Gospels") and 25 in [John](/wiki/Gospel_of_John "Gospel of John"). The five
final amens (Matthew 6:13, 28:20, Mark 16:20, Luke 24:53 and John 21:25),
which are wanting in certain [manuscripts](/wiki/Biblical_manuscripts
"Biblical manuscripts"), simulate the effect of final amen in the Hebrew
[Psalms](/wiki/Psalms "Psalms"). All initial amens occur in the sayings of
Jesus. These initial amens are unparalleled in Hebrew literature, according to
[Friedrich Delitzsch](/wiki/Friedrich_Delitzsch "Friedrich Delitzsch"),
because they do not refer to the words of a previous speaker but instead
introduce a new thought.[18]

The uses of _amen_ ("verily" or "I tell you the truth", depending on the
translation) in the [Gospels](/wiki/Gospels "Gospels") form a peculiar class;
they are initial, but often lack any backward reference.[19]
[Jesus](/wiki/Jesus "Jesus") used the word to affirm his own utterances, not
those of another person[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_], and this usage was adopted by the church. The
use of the initial amen, single or double in form, to introduce solemn
statements of Jesus in the Gospels had no parallel in Jewish practice.[20]

In the [King James Bible](/wiki/King_James_Version_of_the_Bible "King James
Version of the Bible"), the word _amen_ is preserved in a number of contexts.
Notable ones include:

  * The [catechism](/wiki/Catechism "Catechism") of curses of the [Law](/wiki/Torah "Torah") found in [Deuteronomy](/wiki/Deuteronomy "Deuteronomy") 27.[1]
  * A double _amen_ ("amen and amen") occurs in [Psalm](/wiki/Psalm "Psalm") 89 (Psalm 41:13; 72:19; 89:52), to confirm the words and invoke the fulfillment of them.[21]
  * _Amen_ occurs in several [doxology](/wiki/Doxology "Doxology") formulas in [Romans](/wiki/Epistle_to_the_Romans "Epistle to the Romans") 1:25, 9:5, 11:36, 15:33, and several times in Chapter 16.[1] It also appears in doxologies in the Psalms (41:14; 72:19; 89:53; 106:48). This liturgical form from [Judaism](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism").[22]
  * It concludes all of [Paul's](/wiki/Paul_of_Tarsus "Paul of Tarsus") general [epistles](/wiki/Epistle "Epistle").
  * In [Revelation](/wiki/Book_of_Revelation "Book of Revelation") 3:14, Jesus is referred to as, "the Amen, the faithful and true witness, the beginning of God's creation." The whole passage reads as "And unto the angel of the church of the Laodiceans write; These things saith the Amen, the faithful and true witness, the beginning of the creation of God;".
  * _Amen_ concludes the [New Testament](/wiki/New_Testament "New Testament") at Rev. 22:21.

## Religious use[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amen&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Religious use")]

### Judaism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amen&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Judaism")]

See also: [Reciting amen](/wiki/Berakhah#Reciting_amen "Berakhah")

Although amen, in Judaism, is commonly stated as a response to a blessing, it
is also often used as an affirmation of any declaration.

Jewish rabbinical [law](/wiki/Halakha "Halakha") requires an individual to say
_amen_ in a variety of contexts.[23]

With the rise of the synagogue during the [Second Temple](/wiki/Second_Temple
"Second Temple") period, _amen_ became a common response, especially to
benedictions. It is recited communally to affirm a [blessing](/wiki/Brachah
"Brachah") made by the [prayer reader](/wiki/Hazzan "Hazzan"). It is also
mandated as a response during the [kaddish](/wiki/Kaddish "Kaddish") doxology.
The congregation is sometimes prompted to answer 'amen' by the terms _ve-
'imru_ ([Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language"): ואמרו‎) = "and
[now] say (pl.)," or, _ve-nomar_ (ונאמר) = "and let us say." Contemporary
usage reflects ancient practice: As early as the 4th century BCE, Jews
assembled in the [Temple](/wiki/Second_temple "Second temple") responded
'amen' at the close of a doxology or other prayer uttered by a
[priest](/wiki/Kohen "Kohen"). This Jewish [liturgical](/wiki/Liturgical
"Liturgical") use of amen was adopted by the Christians.[20] But [Jewish
law](/wiki/Halakha "Halakha") also requires individuals to answer _amen_
whenever they hear a [blessing](/wiki/Brachah "Brachah") recited, even in a
non-liturgical setting.

The [Talmud](/wiki/Talmud "Talmud") teaches [homiletically](/wiki/Homiletics
"Homiletics") that the word _amen_ is an [acronym](/wiki/Acronym "Acronym")
for **א** ל **מ** לך **נ** אמן (_ʾEl melekh neʾeman_ , "God, trustworthy
King"),[24] the phrase recited silently by an individual before reciting the
[Shma](/wiki/Shma "Shma").

Jews usually approximate the Hebrew pronunciation of the word:
[/ɑːˈmɛn/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [_ah-
MEN_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling
key") (Israeli-[Ashkenazi](/wiki/Ashkenazi_Hebrew "Ashkenazi Hebrew") and
[Sephardi](/wiki/Sephardi_Hebrew_language "Sephardi Hebrew language")) or
[/ɔːˈmeɪn/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [_aw-
MAYN_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling
key") (non-Israeli Ashkenazi).[25]

### Christianity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amen&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Christianity")]

The use of "amen" has been generally adopted in Christian worship as a
concluding word for prayers and hymns and an expression of strong
agreement.[20] The liturgical use of the word in apostolic times is attested
by the passage from 1 Corinthians cited above, and [Justin
Martyr](/wiki/Justin_Martyr "Justin Martyr") (c. 150) describes the
congregation as responding "amen" to the benediction after the celebration of
the Eucharist.[1] Its introduction into the baptismal formula (in the Eastern
Orthodox Church it is pronounced after the name of each person of the Trinity)
was probably later.[26]

In [Isaiah](/wiki/Isaiah "Isaiah") 65:16, the authorized version has "the God
of truth" ("the God of amen" in [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew "Hebrew")). Jesus often
used amen to put emphasis to his own words (translated: "verily"). In John's
Gospel, it is repeated, "Verily, verily". Amen is also used in oaths (Numbers
5:22; Deuteronomy 27:15–26; Nehemiah 5:13; 8:6; 1 Chronicles 16:36) and is
further found at the end of the prayer of primitive churches (1 Corinthians
14:16).[21]

In some Christian [churches](/wiki/Church_\(building\) "Church \(building\)"),
the "amen corner" or "amen section" is any subset of the congregation likely
to call out "Amen!" in response to points in a preacher's
[sermon](/wiki/Sermon "Sermon").[27] Metaphorically, the term can refer to any
group of heartfelt traditionalists or supporters of an authority figure.

_Amen_ is also used in standard, international French, but in [Cajun
French](/wiki/Cajun_French "Cajun French") _Ainsi soit-il_ ("so be it") is
used instead.

Amen is used at the end of the [Lord's Prayer](/wiki/Lord%27s_Prayer "Lord's
Prayer"),[28] which is also called the Our Father or the _Pater Noster_.

### Islam[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amen&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section:
Islam")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f0/Ameen.gif)](/wiki/File:Ameen.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Ameen.gif "Enlarge")

ʾĀmīn in [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic "Arabic").

_ʾĀmīn_ ([Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"): آمين‎) is the
Arabic form of _Amen_. In Islam, it is used with the same meaning as in
Judaism and Christianity; when concluding a prayer, especially after a
[supplication](/wiki/Supplication "Supplication") ([du'a](/wiki/Du%27a
"Du'a")) or reciting the first surah [Al Fatiha](/wiki/Al_Fatiha "Al Fatiha")
of the [Qur'an](/wiki/Qur%27an "Qur'an") ([salat](/wiki/Salat "Salat")), and
as an assent to the prayers of others.[29][30]

## Further reading[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Amen&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
